    Loona is a masterpiece of modern Punjabi poetry. A verse-play, published in 1965, Loona is based on the legend of Puran Bhagat.

        The Legend:

        King of Sialkot marries a young girl Loona. She falls for his son (from 1st wife) Puran who is of her age. He declines her advances; she complains abt him; heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s punished (hands/feet amputated and thrown into a well). A guru rescues him; he gets well and becomes a Bhagat. Years later, Loona still childless comes to Ã¢â‚¬Å“the BhagatÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½. The truth comes out; she admits her mistake; he forgives them and wishes a child, Rasalu.

    ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s how the legend of Puran Bhagar has been told in Punjab for nearly two thousand years. But thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not how Shiv tells is. For Shiv, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the legend of Loona: a girl of lower caste, married against her wishes, falls in love with a man of her age. So what? he asks and retells the legend and makes it about Loona, not the prince-turned-bhagat. A masterpiece at the age of 28! ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s called a great poet.
